Dry reforming of methane (DRM) showed prospective to reduce greenhouse gas emissions if the sintering- and coking-resistant Ni-based catalysts were successfully developed. In this work, emergent Ni nanoparticles embedded in boron nitride supported nickel aluminate spinels were originally developed for DRM. The acidity and basicity derived from nickel aluminate spinels could enhance the decomposition of CH4 and adsorption of CO2, respectively, which provides an ensemble effect with emergent Ni nanoparticles and cooperatively enhances the intrinsic activity. Moreover, the strong metal-support interaction derived from exsolution effects as well as the increased contact interface between nickel aluminate spinels and boron nitride would suppress the metal sintering while the boron nitride could inhibit the carbon deposition. The two-dimensional Raman spectra demonstrated the deposited carbon featured with low graphitic degree in the catalysts. This work provides a novel approach for the development of sintering- and coking-resistant Ni-based catalysts for carbon dioxide reforming of methane. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Dry reforming of methane CO2 conversion Ni-based catalysts Greenhouse gases 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM) is one of the most promising approaches to migrate greenhouse gases as it could convert CO2 and CH4 into value-added syngas (CO and H2) [1–4]. Also, the production of syngas without consumption of water is also of advantageous in some arid area. To achieve such a promising scenario, the highly-efficient catalysts are essential. Among the catalysts explored, Ni-based catalysts showed comparable activity to noble metal based catalysts with much cheaper price [5,6]. However, the carbon deposition and metal sintering, which would lead to serious deactivation, still hindered the wide use of Ni-based catalysts [7,8]. Generally, the high temperature is required for the endothermic DRM reaction which is beyond the Tammann temperature of Ni leading metal sintering [9,10]. Additionally, the decomposition of CH4 and disproportionation of CO would give rise to the serious carbon deposition [11,12]. Previously, coking issues could be alleviated by passivation treatment of the catalysts [13–16], control of the size of Ni NPs [17–20], fabrication of confinement structures [21–24], or alloying with other metals [25–27]. Moreover, the modification of support can also improve the coking resistance for Ni-based catalysts [28–30]. Generally, the control of Ni particle size is also valid to address carbon deposition as the larger size of Ni NPs would lead to more serious carbon deposition [31]. Hence, the adjustment of the interaction between Ni NPs was the promising approach to solve both sintering and coking issues [17,32,33]. Some researchers proposed Ni NPs derived from exsolution showed the strong interaction with the support which can prevent Ni NPs from sintering [34,35]. On the other hand, the coking issue was overcome by using single crystal MgO or porous single crystal MgO despite of the requirement of long activation time [1,36]. Normally, single crystal metal oxides showed less defects and weak interaction with Ni NPs, hence, serious metal sintering would happen during the initial DRM reactions. Although, the mechanism for coke resistance was still unclear, the good coking resistance of the single crystal MgO drawn the increasing interests of other single crystal support. Hexagonal boron nitride (BN) is widely used as a thermally and chemically resistant refractory compound [37]. Basically, BN has a layered structure similar to graphite, in which boron and nitrogen atoms are bound by strong covalent bonds within each layer whereas the layers are held together by weak van der Waals forces [38]. Several works proposed the BN can serve as the novel support for heterogeneous catalysis and exhibited outstanding performance [27,39–41]. Most recently, we fabricated Ni-based catalysts supported by BN and found its better coking resistance compared to the traditional oxides supports [42–44]. However, in terms of the pristine BN, Ni sintering would occur giving rise to the large Ni particles beyond 100 nm. Dong et al. reported stable catalyst by adjusting the solution during impregnation process and found BN would be etched leading to BOx coated Ni NPs [45]. When the BN was exfoliated and defects were introduced, the enhanced metal-supported interaction could alleviate the metal sintering and the coke resistance also maintained. Moreover, the fabrication of composites with BN and metal oxides also displayed promising approach to make use of the benefits of both BN and metal oxides [46]. However, the complicated processing procedures was not favorable for wide applications. It would favorable to develop a novel approach to make use of the pristine BN and achieve both high DRM activity and high coking resistance. In this work, the emergent Ni NPs embedded in boron nitride supported nickel aluminate spinel catalysts were engineered through the exsolution process. Typically, nickel aluminate spinels were deposited on BN, and emergent Ni NPs exsoluted from nickel aluminate spinels after the subsequent reduction. Consequently, the enhanced metal-supported interaction between Ni NPs and nickel aluminate spinels as well as the increased contact interface between BN and nickel aluminate spinels could prevent from the metal sintering. Moreover, the incorporation of BN could inhibit the carbon deposition during DRM reaction. Compared with the pristine BN, the amphotericity of the active ensembles showed enhanced CH4 activation and CO2 adsorption, hence, improved the DRM activity. Our work indicated the cooperative enhancement can be achieved by fabrication of active ensembles over functional supports which also provide an effect approach to tune the properties of supported catalysts to meet the needs of various applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ni-AlO x /BN catalysts. 1.0 g of commercial BN was dispersed into 30 mL anhydrous ethanol; 0.2247 g of Ni(NO3)2.6 H2O and 0.5797 g of Al(NO3)3.9 H2O were added; and then, the suspension underwent magnetic stirring for 6 h at room temperature. Subsequently, 1.0 mol/L (NH4)2CO3 was added into the suspension dropwise until pH reached to 9–10. Then, the suspension was further stirred for 3 h and was vaporized through rotary evaporation at 45 °C and dried at 80 °C overnight. The powder was calcined at 900 °C for 4 h in air at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min and resulted in NiAl2O4/BN. The metal loading was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). The NiAl2O4/BN was reduced by 10% H2/N2 at 30 mL/min at 750 °C for an hour at ramp rate of 10 °C/min and give rise to the Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts. 2.2 Temperature programmed surface reaction-mass spectra (TPSR-MS) CH4-TPSR-MS were carried out using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument connecting with on-line mass spectrum (MS, Pfeiffer Omnistar). The catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min, then cooling down to 50 °C under He. Then, the pure CH4 was injected with temperature programming after the baseline kept stable. The off-gas was detected by online-MS. For the CO2-TPSR-MS, the CH4 was preabsorbed over the catalysts after the pretreatment under the atmosphere of He at 300 °C. Then, the 10 vol% CO2/He was introduced with temperature programming process. The off-gas was tested by online-MS. 2.3 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (In situ DRIFTS) In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on ThermoFischer Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with a liquid nitrogen cooled mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. For the in situ DRIFTS DRM reaction, the catalyst was pretreated with N2 of 30 mL/min at 300 °C for 30 min. Then, the temperature was set at 700 °C and the mixed gases (CH4/CO2/N2 =10/10/30 mL·min−1) was injected. For the in situ DRIFTS transient reaction, the reaction temperature was set as 550 °C. The CO2 (10 mL·min−1) were pre-adsorbed over catalysts for 1 h at 550 °C, then CH4/N2 (10/30 mL·min−1) was introduced during the whole test. Also, the CH4 (10 mL·min−1) were pre-adsorbed over catalysts for 1 h at 550 °C, then CO2/N2 (10 / 30 mL·min−1) was introduced during the whole test. 2.4 Two-dimensional mapping of Raman spectroscopy (2D Raman spectra mapping) 10–20 mg of samples were put into the glass slide. The Raman experiments were carried out on the LabRAM HR Evolution by using 532 nm laser with 5% ND filter and 200-hole value. The spectra were acquired in single window mode where the center value was set as 1500 cm−1. The acquire time and accumulation was set as 1 s and 1, respectively. The step size was set as 4 and the total data points were 42. The 2D Raman spectra mapping was acquired based on the intensity of E2 g band (IE2g) of BN at 1363 cm−1, G band (IG) at 1580 cm−1, and ratio of IG/IE2g. 2.5 Catalytic activity test The catalytic activity and stability of the catalysts were conducted in a quartz fixed-bed tubular reactor. For a typical test, 120 mg of catalysts were diluted by 0.6 g of 20–40 mesh quartz and the reaction temperature were set at 750 °C. The total gas flow rate kept constant at 50 mL/min (CO2/CH4 =25/25 mL/min) with weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 25,000 mL·g−1·h−1. An online GC equipped with TCD detector was used to analysis the content of each component. The conversion of CH4 and CO2 (X%) was calculated based on the following equation: X CH 4 (%)= [ CH 4 ] in - [ CH 4 ] out [ CH 4 ] in X CO 2 (%)= [ CO 2 ] in - [ CO 2 ] out [ CO 2 ] in Where [CH4]in, [CO2]in, [CH4]out, and [CO2]out are the inlet and outlet volume flow rates of CH4 and CO2, respectively. The H2/CO ratio of product was determined by: H 2 CO = H 2 produced CO produced The turnover frequencies (TOF, s−1) were calculated according following equation: TOF = n CH 4 m catal × W Ni × D M Ni Where nCH4 is molar conversion rate of CH4 tested at 650 °C with WHSV of 250, 000 mL·g−1·h−1. mcatal is the weight of catalyst used, WNi is the mass fraction of Ni in catalysts, D is the metal dispersion determined by H2-pluse measurement. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of catalysts Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts were prepared via a coprecipitation approach, followed by calcination and reduction with 10% H2-N2 at 750 °C ( Fig. 1 A). As a comparison, Ni/BN catalysts were fabricated without addition of Al precursors (Fig. S1). The formation of spinel in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts before reduction was confirmed by UV–vis spectra where two bands in 601 nm and 643 nm was ascribed to the tetrahedral Ni2+ in spinel (Fig. 1B). The high content of Ni2+ in NiAl2O4/BN demonstrates the presence of nickel aluminate spinel structure. The adsorption band at 240 nm corresponding to the characterized peak of BN which appeared in both NiO/BN and NiAl2O4/BN suggesting the presence of BN in the as-prepared samples. It is evident that the deposition of nickel aluminate spinels over BN could increase contact interface and enhance the interaction which would suppress the sintering during high temperature reaction conditions. In addition, the Tammann temperature of aluminate spinel is about 1064 °C which is much higher than that of Ni (590 °C). Hence, the aluminate spinel provides a robust “ground” for the Ni NPs. The adsorption band at 318 nm was not obvious in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts indicating most of the Ni was present as the nickel aluminate spinel. The reduction peaks were observed at 533 and 610 °C in the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profile (Fig. S2). While the reduction of nickel aluminate spinel moved to higher temperature suggesting the strong interaction between Ni NPs with the support compared to Ni/BN catalyst (Fig. S2). The H2 consumption during the H2-TPR process is 0.86 and 0.019 mmol/gcat for Ni/BN and Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts, respectively. The H2 consumption in the Ni/BN catalyst is similar to the theoretical numbers while the H2 consumption in Ni-AlOx/BN is much smaller than the theoretical counterpart which suggests most of the Ni is contained in the NiAl2O4 spinels. As displayed in Fig. 1 C, a distinct peak corresponding to the BN were observed in the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts, indicating high crystallinity of the BN. The peak appeared in 44°, 52°, and 76° were indexed to the (111), (200), and (220) of Ni (PDF#04–0850) in both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts. Different from Ni/BN catalysts, two hump peaks emerged at 38° and 67° in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts which was ascribed to the NiAl2O4. Fig. S3A and B summarize the results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) over Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts, in which the content of Ni0 was 26% in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts which was lower than that of Ni/BN catalysts (38%). The high content of Ni2+ in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts compared to Ni/BN catalysts was attributed the presence of nickel aluminate spinel. To further understand the structure of each component, the scanning electron microscopy coupling with energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) was implemented. The Al and O are overlapped with each other forming the ensembles supported by BN as confirmed by SEM-EDS results ( Fig. 2). The isolated Ni NPs popped out from the surface of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts and anchored by the nickel aluminate spinels. Besides the aggregation of Ni in the exsolution NPs, the well overlap of Ni, Al, and O demonstrated the presence of nickel aluminate spinels. The well composite structure was also confirmed by the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images along with the elemental mapping (Fig. S4). As a comparison, larger Ni NPs were distributed on the BN surface (Fig. S5). The homogeneous distribution of Ni NPs over Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts was displayed by TEM images (Fig. S6A), while the big aggregations was observed in Ni/BN catalysts (Fig. S6B). The average Ni particle size of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts is 17.9 ± 3.6 nm which was smaller than that of Ni/BN catalysts (48.6 ± 20.0 nm) ( Table 1, Fig. S6A and B). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of Ni-AlOx/BN catalyst was collected to identify the crystal structure ( Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 3 A, the overlapping of three different crystal structure suggested the well interaction between each component. The interplanar space of the specific area labeled in Fig. 3 A was measured (Fig. 3B). The lattice space of nanoparticle was 0.198 nm corresponding the Ni(111) plane. Additionally, the lattice space of 0.24 nm was ascribed to nickel aluminate spinel (200) plane while the 0.35 nm was attributed to the interlayer space distance of the BN. Based the characterization above, the Ni-AlOx ensembles supported by BN were well constructed, where the smaller Ni NPs formed through exsolution than that of Ni/BN catalysts. 3.2 Surficial acidity and basicity of catalysts The acidity in catalysts, which could facilitate the decomposition of CH4 [47–49], were measured via ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) ( Fig. 4 A). Compared to the Ni/BN catalysts, the extra peaks at 375 °C and 466 °C contributed by nickel aluminate spinel which suggested the stronger acidity and more acidic sites in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts. The desorption peak of NH3 in Ni/BN catalysts at 410 °C, which was also observed in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts, should come from the coordination adsorption of metallic Ni. The acidity in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts could be derived from aluminum oxides including both the coordinatively unsaturated Al cations and terminal hydroxyl groups. Furthermore, the CO2-TPD-MS was conducted to explore the basicity of the catalysts because the acid gas (CO2) which was also the reactant in DRM could be used to titrated basic sites. As shown in Fig. 4B, the CO2 desorption amount over Ni-AlOx/BN catalyst was larger than that of Ni/BN catalysts which suggested there were more basic sites in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts compared to Ni/BN catalysts (Fig. 4 C). Additionally, an obvious CO peak emerged at 450 °C over Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts which was lower than that of Ni/BN catalysts (470 °C) (Fig. 4B and C), indicating a better CO2 activation ability of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts. To sum up, the nickel aluminate spinels endow Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts with more acidic and basic sites which would be favorable for DRM reaction. 3.3 Temperature programmed surface reaction over catalysts Subsequently, the activation of CH4 was explored via CH4-TPSR-MS as displayed in Fig. 5 A. CH4 would under decomposition and gave rise to H2. The H2 signal emerged since 400 °C for Ni-AlOx/BN catalyst and quickly reached the first peak at 408 °C. Afterwards, the continuous decomposition of CH4 happened with the release of H2 (Fig. 5 A, upper). As a comparison, a weak signal of H2 started to appear at 400 °C for Ni/BN catalysts and the obvious decomposition began since 443 °C (Fig. 5 A, lower). It should be noted that a maximum H2 signal appeared at 720 °C for Ni/BN catalysts which might attributed to the coverage of deposited carbon during decomposition of CH4. Hence, Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts exhibited a better activation for CH4 than Ni/BN catalysts but with less carbon deposition. To understand the influence between two reactants, CH4 was pre-adsorbed for 1 h under 50 °C and CO2 was continually injected within the temperature programming process. As showed in Fig. 5 A, H2 evolution began at 340 °C and reached at the maximum at 445 °C which was lower than that of Ni/BN catalysts (500 °C). The initial H2 evolution within injection of CO2 was lower than that sole CH4-TPSR-MS of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts suggesting CO2 could facilitate the decomposition of CH4. The active oxygen species during activation of CO2 could contribute to the crack of C-H band. Furthermore, the earlier emergence of CO at 451 °C and 475 °C over Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts compared to that of Ni/BN catalyst (508 °C) (Fig. 5B) demonstrated the better activation of CO2 in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts. Furthermore, the temperature of CO evolution in CO2-TPSR-MS with pre-adsorption of CH4 was comparable to sole CO2-TPD results, which suggested the contribution from CH4 for the activation of CO2 was not notable. Hence, the amphotericity of nickel aluminate spinel ensembles enabled Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts with better activation towards both CH4 and CO2 than Ni/BN catalysts, and the CO2 could facilitate the activation of CH4 during DRM reaction. 3.4 DRM performance of catalysts The DRM performance of the as-prepared catalysts was explored with WHSV of 25,000 mL∙g−1∙h−1 at 750 °C. The conversion of CH4 and CO2 is negligible when there is no catalyst filled (Fig. S7). The initial conversion of CH4 and CO2 was 86.5% and 88.4% for Ni/BN catalysts which dropped to 62.5% and 69.4% ( Fig. 6) after 20 h DRM reaction, respectively. Compared to Ni/BN catalysts, the CH4 conversion of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts declined from 86.5% to 79.2% within the first 10 h DRM reaction, then, kept constant (Fig. 6). There was almost no degradation for the CO2 conversion of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts during the 20 h DRM reaction. Moreover, a repeatability study was conducted and the time on stream was extended to 50 h where Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts still exhibit better stability (Fig. S8) than that of Ni/BN catalysts. These results suggested Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts owned a better stability than Ni/BN catalysts for DRM reaction. The TOFCH4 and TOFCO2 of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts at 650 °C was 5.6 ± 0.8 s−1 and 10.8 ± 3.0 s−1 (Table 1) which was much higher than that of Ni/BN catalysts (TOFCH4 of 1.0 ± 0.1 s−1 and TOFCO2 of 1.3 ± 0.6 s−1). Moreover, the activity of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts are ahead of other catalysts in terms of the activity and coke resistance (Table S1). 3.5 Properties of spent catalysts The results of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the spent catalysts exhibited that more carbon deposition (5.8 wt%) happened to Ni/BN catalysts compared to that of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts (2.2 wt%) ( Fig. 7 A). The carbon accumulation also decreases the specific surface area of both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts (Fig. S9). When the BN was removed, the Ni/AlOx catalyst shows better activity (Fig. S10) for DRM, however, more deposited carbon (6.4 wt%) was observed which confirm the critical role of BN for coking resistance. The results of TGA are consistent with the temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) results where the higher consumption amount of O2 for the spent Ni/BN catalysts (1.56 mmol/g vs 0.48 mmol/g) demonstrate there is less deposited carbon in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts (Fig. 7B). The similar oxidation temperature of the spent Ni-AlOx/BN (638 °C) and Ni/BN catalysts (654 °C) suggests the similar stability of the deposited carbon. In order to monitor the properties of deposited carbon in the whole catalysts, the 2D Raman spectra mapping was collected within the micro scale. There was some white and bright area besides the black one (Fig. S11). Based on the 2D Raman spectra mapping, the inhomogeneous distribution of coke was found. Similar phenomena were observed in the spent Ni/BN catalysts (Fig. S12). Generally, D band located at 1344 cm−1 was attributed to disorder carbon, while the G band at 1580 cm−1 was ascribed to graphitic carbon. The D band was overlapped by characteristic peak of BN-derived E2 g phonon mode. Hence, the E2 g band of BN was used as the interior label and the IG/IE2g was used to evaluate the carbon deposition. The 2D Raman mapping based on IG/IE2g was acquired (Fig. 7 C and D) to reveal the improvement of BN for coke resistance. The region with the stronger signal of BN has less carbon as shown in Fig. 7 C and D. The assemble of the deposited carbon suggested the coking only happened surround the Ni NPs and the BN exhibited coking resistance properties. Moreover, the deposited carbon was more concentrated in the spent Ni/BN catalysts while the deposited carbon in the spent Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts was more dispersed which would leaded to more serious degradation of activation in Ni/BN catalysts. Subsequently, the Raman spectra collected in the most serious coking area between spent Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts was compared (Fig. 7E). A narrow full width at half maximum (FWHM) of G band in spent Ni/BN catalyst suggested higher graphitic degree of deposited carbon (Fig. 7E). The lower graphitic degree of deposited carbon in the spent Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts would lead to easier removal of the carbon which was confirmed via in situ Raman spectra (Figs. S13 and S14). The 002 peak of deposited carbon is only observed in the XRD pattern of the spent Ni/BN catalysts but not the spent Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts (Fig. S15). Additionally, the NiAl2O4 spinels also emerge in the XRD patterns of spent Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts indicating the well stability of the spinels. The spent catalysts were also characterized by SEM (Fig. S16), in which the carbon nanotubes or aggregations was hardly seen in the spent Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts. However, the serious aggregation was observed in the spent Ni/BN catalysts besides the graphitic carbon nanotubes (Fig. S17 and Table 1). Moreover, the BN was etched in the spent Ni/BN catalysts which would further destroy the support (Fig. S18) and was also reported in recent literature [45]. By contrast, the etching issue was relieved in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts. It might be attributed to the buffering of the nickel aluminate spinels which separate the direct interaction between Ni and BN. The particle size of spent Ni/BN catalysts is 50.8 ± 28 nm which is much larger than that of spent Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts (21.8 ± 6.3 nm) and the large relative error bar also imply the serious sintering happen for spent Ni/BN catalysts. According to above results, the Ni NPs embedded in nickel aluminate spinel supported by boron nitride exhibited improved activity and robust stability than Ni/BN catalysts. The enhanced activity for DRM should originate from the improved activation of CH4 and CO2 derived from the amphotericity of nickel aluminate spinel. The strong interaction between nickel aluminate spinel and Ni NPs would alleviate the aggregation of Ni NPs, and the BN would inhibit the accumulation of carbon. Hence, the active Ni-AlOx catalysts supported by boron nitride make use of two functional components achieving a cooperative improvement of catalytic performance. 3.6 Possible reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism was monitored via in situ steady-state diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTs) reaction at 700 °C by injecting CH4 and CO2. For both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts ( Fig. 8A and B), the bands appearing at 1630, 1663, 1671, and 2070 cm−1 can be assigned to monodentate carbonate, bidentate carbonate, monodentate formate, and CO, respectively. The same intermediates observed in both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts indicates the DRM reaction mechanism is similar but with different efficiency as the variation of intermates is different. As shown in Fig. 8, the absorbance variation was plotted by subtracting the spectra at 0 s to track the formation and consumption of intermediates (Fig. 8C). The monodentate carbonate would be formed and consumed for both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts in which a higher frequency was found in Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts indicating a faster conversion of intermediates. Furthermore, the higher accumulation of monodentate formate over Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts than that of Ni/BN catalysts suggested a faster formation of effective intermediates. Additionally, the accumulation of bidentate carbonate for both Ni-AlOx/BN and Ni/BN catalysts demonstrated the subsequent transformation was sluggish. The effective conversion process was also confirmed by the high concentration of CO adsorbed on Ni-AlOx/BN catalyst. The reaction efficiency was then explored in situ transient DRIFTs measurements. The CO2 was injected after pre-adsorption of CH4 as shown in Figs. S18 and S19 in which the CH4 consumption rates of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts was higher than that of Ni/BN catalysts. Simultaneously, the CO2 consumption of Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts was also more efficient than that of Ni/BN catalysts when CH4 was purged into the catalysts pre-adsorbed of CO2. According to the results derived from chemsorption, TPSR, and in situ DRIFTs experiment, the DRM reaction mechanism on Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts can be proposed as following ( Fig. 9). The CH4 and CO2 dissociation over Ni would occur parallelly which also reported in other literature. Additionally, the H atom produced due to CH4 dissociation would be also involved into the CO2 activation [50]. The CH4 would adsorb on metallic Ni and decompose into CHx * species and H2, the acidic nickel aluminate spinel could accelerate this process. One the other hand, the nickel aluminate spinel could enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2. The active oxygen species derived from activation of CO2 would be further involved into the conversion of CHx * species and given rise to CO. Additionally, the hydrogenation of adsorption of CO2 and CO3 * would result into formate and carbonate. Subsequentially, the formate could decompose into CO and H2 while the continuous hydrogenation of carbonate could result into formate and produce H2O. The increased contact interface between BN and nickel aluminate spinels could suppress the mobility of metal oxides while the enhanced interaction between the exsoluted Ni NPs and nickel aluminate spinels could alleviate the sintering of Ni NPs. Furthermore, the incorporation of nickel aluminate spinel endowed Ni-AlOx/BN catalysts with amphoteric properties which could boost the activity of DRM reaction and the BN could inhibit the carbon deposition. 4 Conclusions In this work, we originally fabricated the BN supported ensembles consisting of emergent Ni NPs exsoluted from nickel aluminate spinels which made use of the amphoteric oxides and BN enabling enhanced DRM activity and coking resistance. Compared to the inert BN, the acidity of the nickel aluminate spinels would facilitate the decomposition of CH4 while the basicity of nickel aluminate spinels could enhance the adsorption of CO2 which would cooperatively promote the DRM reaction. Additionally, the emergent Ni NPs exsolution from nickel aluminate spinel exhibited a strong metal-support interaction which suppressed the metal sintering during DRM reaction while the BN inhibited the carbon deposition during DRM reaction. The active catalysts fabricated here provided an alternative strategy to optimize functional supports enabling a synergetic improvement of the catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) showed prospective to reduce greenhouse gas emissions if the sintering- and coking-resistant Ni-based catalysts were successfully developed. In this work, emergent Ni nanoparticles embedded in boron nitride supported nickel aluminate spinels were originally developed for DRM. The acidity and basicity derived from nickel aluminate spinels could enhance the decomposition of CH4 and adsorption of CO2, respectively, which provides an ensemble effect with emergent Ni nanoparticles and cooperatively enhances the intrinsic activity. Moreover, the strong metal-support interaction derived from exsolution effects as well as the increased contact interface between nickel aluminate spinels and boron nitride would suppress the metal sintering while the boron nitride could inhibit the carbon deposition. The two-dimensional Raman spectra demonstrated the deposited carbon featured with low graphitic degree in the catalysts. This work provides a novel approach for the development of sintering- and coking-resistant Ni-based catalysts for carbon dioxide reforming of methane.
coredata.dc:title: Sintering- and coking-resistant nickel catalysts embedded in boron nitride supported nickel aluminate spinels for dry reforming of methane
